name: TheAtlantic
text: "When police treat demonstrators as illegitimate intruders in the people’s streets, when they respond to peaceable assembly with weapons of war, they too break the law—America’s fundamental law, the Constitution," @profepps writes: https://t.co/DRAOD2yPbw

name: TheAtlantic
text: If a picture is worth a thousand words, a staged photo op outside the White House succinctly tells the story of the Trump presidency. The latest Atlantic Daily, from @mimbsy: https://t.co/d6WHzY2Ywo

name: TheAtlantic
text: From seizing control of the internet to declaring martial law, Trump may legally do all kinds of extraordinary things during a state of emergency. @LizaGoitein outlines the special provisions that become available to the president. https://t.co/6rc7tS3w8b https://t.co/AOJ6RJtfkh

name: TheAtlantic
text: “There are no eulogies, no last words, and the corpses are no longer moved to manicured graveyards,” Ai Weiwei writes. “One loses belief in the government, in parents, in neighbors, in the very possibility that life will continue.” https://t.co/fWLnjj24os

name: TheAtlantic
text: Biden portrayed this week’s events as a turning point for America—and as a binary choice in visions for its future, @IsaacDovere writes. https://t.co/A2Ht55DKEq

name: TheAtlantic
text: As protests rage across America, the president has posed in front of an Episcopal church and a Catholic shrine to signal religious unity. But many Christians reject his message, @emmaogreen reports. https://t.co/TCr4Qe3CpQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: The prospect of martial law, while still remote, is not purely hypothetical in the current crisis, the law professors Stephen Dycus and William C. Banks wrote in March. Here’s what it could look like. https://t.co/uL65Bglx0g

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: "I have to date been reticent to speak out on issues surrounding President Trump's leadership, but we are at an inflection point and events of the last few weeks have made it impossible to remain silent," Mike Mullen writes: https://t.co/uBCPxoPUAl

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @russellberman: Steve King has lost his seat in Congress. Read @elainejgodfrey on the factors that did—and did not—bring him down: https://t.co/HVmAWV5x93

name: TheAtlantic
text: "We have patchwork protests, mixed with patchwork riots. In each one of them, the police and the protesters have different motives, create different impacts, affect people in different ways," @anneapplebaum writes: https://t.co/VGhVwGJkVX

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @anneapplebaum: "The question now is whether the old American mantras, the appeals to traditions of democracy and the rule of law, still work—or whether they have now become just another competing narrative in the information war."  https://t.co/lSA8BRAHZs

name: TheAtlantic
text: "What we desperately need, but have so far lacked, is political will. America needs to do more than throw good reform dollars at bad agencies," @PoliceLawProf, Jeffrey J. Noble, and Geoffrey Alpert write: https://t.co/Ig76Z9gbte

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The real demonstration of military courage by a general in such a situation is not resignation. It is, rather, the willingness to be fired," @EliotACohen writes: https://t.co/yx2ElGAIfn

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Many of Trump’s statements are self-executing. Therein lies their power. Never mind what the courts say tomorrow; he speaks the law as it is understood and applied today," Jane Chong writes: https://t.co/Yoh5mEtFqh

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @elainejgodfrey: Good morning. In case you missed it somehow, Iowa congressman Steve King lost his primary election to @RandyFeenstra. Here's how it happened: https://t.co/nOSAm1l7uQ

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "Presidential speech is never just speech. Because law enforcement begins with the simple act of legal interpretation, presidential speech is presidential action." -- Jane Chong in @TheAtlantic:
https://t.co/tGNMtGtHLv

name: TheAtlantic
text: Media reports have a huge influence on the public's opinion of police violence at recent protests. @sjjphd on why the passive, euphemistic language in some news stories stifles racial progress: https://t.co/kjKWvAshw4

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @megangarber: Read @sjjphd on the scourge of sentient pepper spray—and on the ways media coverage of protests can obscure and therefore abet police brutality

https://t.co/vkY9slwCaC https://t.co/yQLEkR99zI
